image.altText: Glenn Stevens

items.synopsis: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) warns further interest rate increases are still possible, as a former RBA governor says the low-rate era is over, leaving households feeling like Australia is heading for recession.

title.children: Former RBA boss warns interest rates unlikely to fall amid 'once-in-a-generation' inflation battle

image.altText: A firefighter is seen through one of two scorched windows

items.synopsis: Emergency services teams begin work to assess the fatal fire at Loafers Lodge, determined to understand how the tragedy occurred.

title.children: Ninety-two rooms, full beds and no sprinklers: Investigations begin into NZ hostel fire

image.altText: Julia Gillard sitting at a meeting table in a city office and speaking.

items.synopsis: Former prime minister Julia Gillard concedes that her desire to have a debate around the merit of marriage in modern society, instead of supporting same-sex marriage itself, was "wrong".

title.children: Gillard says she 'got it incredibly wrong' on same-sex marriage debate

image.altText: Victoria, who has shoulder-length blonde hair, looks calmly at the camera in a close-up portrait.

items.synopsis: On the day former police officer Brett Johnson is sentenced for abusing his position of power to pursue vulnerable women, one of his victims speaks exclusively to the ABC about the devastating impact his offending had on her life.

title.children: A police officer's misconduct shattered Victoria's life. He has today been jailed for six months

image.altText: Katy, a middle-aged woman in a salmon-pink top, sits at a table looking serious

items.synopsis: Home owner Katy says she's been struggling to meet her loan demands, and fears losing her home. What are the steps between missing a payment and losing your property?

title.children: Australians sell investment properties, refinance mortgages 'at a rate never before seen'

items.synopsis: Ningaloo's sparkling turquoise waters and marine life are well known to many, but this World Heritage treasure extends to the land, too — and conservationists fear its future is on a knife's edge.

title.children: A breathtaking journey into one of the last intact wild places on Earth

image.altText: A fire truck outside a building that is burnt on the top.

items.synopsis: A fire at Wellington's Loafers Lodge hostel is being treated as suspicious by authorities as people remain unaccounted-for.

title.children: Deadly New Zealand hostel blaze being treated as suspicious

image.altText: A person in all white protective gear treating a big area of black mould on the wall of a house

items.synopsis: Rental properties are more likely be mouldy than other homes and excessive mould growth is known to harm human health. So what can you do about it?

title.children: We're heading in to 'mega mould' season and renters are at greater risk

image.altText: Dr Janin Bredehoeft 1

items.synopsis: An embarrassing day is coming for Australian businesses that have a large gender pay gap, with the data from individual organisations to be made public.

title.children: 'Your gender pay gap is X, why would I go and work for you?': The revealing day coming for Australian businesses

image.altText: A screen shot of Paul Kent speaking on Fox Sports' NRL 360 program.

items.synopsis: NRL 360 host Braith Anasta says "Paul Kent is stood down while he deals with personal issues" after domestic violence charges are laid against the prominent News Corp and Fox Sports journalist.

title.children: Prominent journalist Paul Kent stood down from Fox Sports show over domestic violence charges

image.altText: Two riders on horses in forested area.

items.synopsis: Police are declining to speculate on whether the remains are those of the young man, but say they are treating the discovery as linked to the investigation into his disappearance.

title.children: Human remains found in WA bushland near last known location of missing 26-year-old

image.altText: A black and white image of a dam that has been blown apart.

items.synopsis: Today marks 80 years since the Dambusters Raid during World War II, a mission so secretive the crews didn't even know their target until the night before.

title.children: The WWII mission from 'hell' that saw pilots fly just above water at 370 kph in enemy territory

image.altText: A composite image of three women. One of the women holds a baby.

items.synopsis: Hopes, dreams, and disappointment. Five women aged between 24 and 41 share their stories of egg freezing.

title.children: Dreams and disappointments: Women share their stories of egg freezing

image.altText: The 'big four'

items.synopsis: Australia's under-pressure banks unveil a new tool to combat scam transactions, but consumer groups say they're still not doing enough to deal with an escalating problem.

title.children: Banks launch new weapon to help recover scam victims' money

image.altText: Long animal livestock transport truck parked on the side of the road, sunset in the background.

items.synopsis: Truck drivers say smaller vehicles are the leading cause of crashes involving heavy haulage vehicles and that more education is needed.

title.children: Truckies call out 'ridiculous behaviour' of drivers in smaller vehicles amid claims accidents increasing

image.altText: A graphic showing a corporate headshot of Richard Boyle with redacted cuttings from company documents behind him.

items.synopsis: It's a crisis that calls into question the wisdom of government outsourcing crucial functions and highlights the often cosy relationship between government, bureaucracy, regulators and the corporate world, writes Ian Verrender.

title.children: Richard Boyle faces life behind bars while those in the PwC scandal are protected by the corporate world

image.altText: Beau McCreery hugs his mum on the oval with a mother's day banner in the background

items.synopsis: Collingwood's Beau McCreery had no idea his mum had been invited to deliver a rev-up speech to players before Sunday's Mother's Day game.

title.children: 'Rip it up, boys': Beau McCreery's mum has Pies players in stitches with surprise pre-game speech

image.altText: A skate lying on the seabed.

items.synopsis: Researchers say Tanya Plibersek's pledge of no new extinctions is under serious threat as the only known population of an endangered ancient Tasmania ray continues to nosedive.

title.children: 'They're just not there': A rare, ancient Australian skate is on thin ice as populations plunge

image.altText: A dog sits in a sling as people in red coats gather around it.

items.synopsis: A dog is rescued after hiking up Scafell Pike and becoming too exhausted to walk back down.

title.children: Dog rescued from England's tallest mountain after injuring itself

image.altText: A drago queen with a green and pick hat blowing confetti.

items.synopsis: Betty Confetti's Rainbow Story Time show is intended to promote diversity and inclusion, but it has been called off at a regional NSW library due to safety concerns.

title.children: Drag queen's library show for children cancelled after staff threatened

image.altText: Joe Biden at a lectern.

items.synopsis: Renewing the agreements has become a key part of US efforts to push back against China's bid to expand its influence in the Pacific.

title.children: US to renew strategic pact with Federated States of Micronesia in bid to counter China

image.altText: Handcuffed prisoner being led in corridor by warden.

items.synopsis: A woman who was employed by Queensland Correction Services was found to have been in a relationship with an inmate and in possession of 195 strips of an illegal drug.

title.children: Ex-prison guard who was caught with illegal drugs pleads guilty to intimate relationship with prisoner

image.altText: An underwater image with part of a shipwreck and fish

items.synopsis: A diver who found a human bone protuding from the sea floor says the discovery has sat with him "more deeply" because of what it could mean for people with missing loved ones.

title.children: Human bone discovered at Byron Bay shipwreck had been in water 'at most a couple of months'

image.altText: A hand holds large hailstones

items.synopsis: Some areas have received a month's worth of rain overnight, while Tuesday morning commuters on the M1 have been delayed by flash flooding on the Gold Coast.

title.children: Storms lash south-east Qld, dumping heavy rain and hail

image.altText: A composite image of Prince, The Weeknd and Kanye West performing on stage

items.synopsis: The Weeknd's name change comes after the award-winning artist told W Magazine that he wanted to "kill The Weeknd" — and he's not the only artist to ditch their stage name.

title.children: The Weeknd reverts to his real name, Abel Tesfaye, joining prominent artists in killing their stage names

image.altText: an oil drill in the outback

items.synopsis: South Australia's energy minister launches defence of gas industry, saying his state's global leadership in the switch to green power would not be possible without the fuel.

title.children: 'No transition without gas': Renewable energy leader South Australia defends fossil fuel

image.altText: A four-wheel-drive towing a caravan along a bitumen road, captured by drone, surrounded by red dirt and small green shrubs.

items.synopsis: Some operators are experiencing a 50 per cent drop in visitor numbers and fear financial impacts should foot traffic not increase soon.

title.children: Where are all the tourists? Outback suffers worst start to peak season in four years

image.altText: Ukrainian service members from a 3rd separate assault brigade of the Armed Forces of Ukraine.

items.synopsis: While the UK prime minister says his country alone cannot supply Ukraine with fighter jets, he pledges to support Volodymyr Zelenskyy in the creation of a "jets coalition" between allies.

title.children: Ukraine claims battlefield gains in Bakhmut as Zelenskky's Europe tour secures more weapons

image.altText: A man stands in front of red and green indicator boards.

items.synopsis: Australian shares fall in afternoon trade, while the Reserve Bank warns there may be further interest rate hikes, and consumer confidence sinks to its lowest levels since the early days of the COVID-19 pandemic and the 1990s recession.

title.children: ASX slips, Reserve Bank warns of further rate hikes, consumer confidence sinks to COVID-19 lows

liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Market snapshot at 12:42pm AEST

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Speaking at the APPEA oil and gas conference, former RBA governor Glenn Stevens was also asked about the impact of the federal budget on the economy, which saw a return surplus for the first time in 15 years. Mr Stevens praised the federal government for using the windfall from higher revenue to put the budget temporarily back into the black. "What the economy did for the budget was a large control gain in the bottom line because of strong growth, high commodity prices, and so on," Mr Stevens said. "I think it's to the government's credit that they've allowed most of that to flow through to the bottom line." "That's the right thing to do." The federal opposition and some economists argue that the billions of dollars in spending could fuel inflation and make the Reserve Bank's job harder. But Mr Stevens doesn't think there will be much impact. "I would assess....that the budget is slightly expansionary," he said. "Its implication for interest rates and inflation, I think, to be honest, not that much really." "The budget is what it is." "There's a dozen other things also affecting the economy, this is just one of them."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Glenn Stevens says not much budget impact on inflation

children.content: Speaking at the APPEA oil and gas conference, former RBA governor Glenn Stevens was also asked about the impact of the federal budget on the economy, which saw a return surplus for the first time in 15 years.
Mr Stevens praised the federal government for using the windfall from higher revenue to put the budget temporarily back into the black.
the budget was a large control gain in
the bottom line because of strong growth, high commodity prices, and so on," Mr Stevens said.
"I think it's to the government's credit that they've allowed most of that to flow through to the bottom line."
The federal opposition and some economists argue that the billions of dollars in spending could fuel inflation and make the Reserve Bank's job harder.
But Mr Stevens doesn't think there will be much impact.
"I would assess....that the budget is slightly expansionary," he said.
"Its implication for interest rates and inflation, I think, to be honest, not that much really."
"There's a dozen other things also affecting the economy, this is just one of them."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Reserve Bank has shed some light on why it decided to raise interest rates earlier this month — which caught markets (and most economists) by surprise. Inflation risks from weak productivity growth, persistently high inflation in the services sector and faster-than-forecast rent increases were the reasons behind the RBA's latest rate hike, according to the minutes of its May board meeting (released today). The board members also considered a pause, but ultimately decided the high inflation risks warranted a 0.25 percentage rate point increase (after holding rates steady in April). "In weighing up the two options, members recognised that the arguments were finely balanced but judged it appropriate to increase interest rates at his meeting," the RBA minutes noted. "Members also agreed that further increases in interest rates may still be required, but that this would depend on how the economy and inflation evolve." Annual inflation is not expected to fall to 3% (the top of the RBA's target range) until mid-2025, leaving little room for upside risks, the May minutes said. The RBA board members also noted strong employment data and high services price inflation in March (along with the weaker Australian dollar and rising house prices) may have been in part caused by the central bank's decision to pause rates in April. Governor Philip Lowe has warned that the RBA cannot take too long to being inflation to heel. Rates have already risen by a whopping 375 basis points since last May to an 11-year high of 3.85%. Markets have priced an 85% chance of a pause in June, while seeing a higher risk of a hike in August or September.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Reserve Bank explains reasons behind 'surprise' rate hike in May

children.content: The Reserve Bank has shed some light on why it decided to raise interest rates earlier this month — which caught markets (and most economists) by surprise.
were the reasons behind the RBA's latest rate hike, according to the minutes of its May board meeting (released today).
The board members also considered a pause, but ultimately decided the high inflation risks warranted a 0.25 percentage rate point increase (after holding rates steady in April).
"In weighing up the two options, members recognised that the arguments were finely balanced but judged it appropriate to increase interest rates at his meeting," the RBA minutes noted.
"Members also agreed that further increases in interest rates may still be required, but that this would depend on how the economy and inflation evolve."
Annual inflation is not expected to fall to 3% (the top of the RBA's target range) until mid-2025, leaving little room for upside risks, the May minutes said.

The RBA board members also noted strong employment data and high services price inflation in March (along with the weaker Australian dollar and rising house prices) may have been in part caused by the central bank's decision to pause rates in April.
Governor Philip Lowe has warned that the RBA cannot take too long to being inflation to heel.
Rates have already risen by a whopping 375 basis points since last May to an 11-year high of 3.85%.
Markets have priced an 85% chance of a pause in June, while seeing a higher risk of a hike in August or September.

image.altText: A group of people stand in an industrial kitchen holding a plate of food ready to serve during a busy service at Matt's Place.

items.synopsis: Demand for a twice-weekly free community meal program has almost doubled in a year as residents across Melbourne's bayside suburbs feel the pinch.

title.children: Volunteer army steps up to meet rising demand for food relief

image.altText: A woman with her hands on another woman's back

items.synopsis: Traditional ochre paint, sacred songs and massage complement Western medicine at a health service in WA's north — and there are hopes this "sacred knowledge" can be passed on to the region's young people.

title.children: Born amid a youth suicide crisis, this traditional healing program is in high demand

image.altText: A collection of Chiang Kai-shek statues lumped together in a park

items.synopsis: Taiwan is littered with monuments to one of its most divisive leaders. However, as efforts to remove them stall, some activists to are taking matters into their own hands.

title.children: Statues of a 'ruthless' dictator are all over Taiwan. His critics keep dumping them in this park
